Blizzard perma banned my six and a half year old account.

fuck offf you piece of shit

I have thousands of hours on this game through battle.net 

There are plenty of ups and downs but it all comes down to netcode in multiplayer fps games. And when it comes to netcode Overwatch is still the industry leader. 

There are plenty of issues around the company, but the game started from developers that genuinely love and wanted to progress the multiplayer FPS format even if they failed at a lot of things. Some of the biggest arguments I have seen are not exclusive to any similar development company.  

If anything I was upset and left for season 5 because certain devs walked out within the two seasons before it. This started the brain drain of a company struggling to handle multiple issues on multiple fronts. 

This all being said there is still a lot of potential in this game, particularly if they can get away from the activision big corpa drain the customers bank accounts strategy for success. It also might very well die and never ever live up to its potential. 

All I know is that I do enjoy the Hero's they release, the skins are nice bonus but not necessary to me. The players can be a mixed bag, but I think the FPS community is improving over the years. 

For new players there is a huge memory dump of information and meta, that has no shortage in online content creators helping you understand. 

Go into it with an open mind and willing to learn and you might just enjoy yourself outside the expectations of the internet hate machine.

GPT-3.5ï¼šRecently, the announcement of Activision Blizzard's decision to exit the Chinese market has garnered widespread attention and discussion. As a globally renowned gaming company with a long-standing presence, this move by Activision Blizzard is not only surprising but has also triggered strong condemnation from many quarters.

First and foremost, Activision Blizzard holds a significant user base and influence in the Chinese market. Exiting this market signifies relinquishing access to millions of Chinese gamers, as well as forfeiting a substantial potential source of profit. This could have considerable repercussions on the company's long-term growth and the job stability of its employees.

Secondly, the potential for a public relations crisis resulting from this exit is also a cause for concern. In this era of information explosion, voices on social media can quickly garner widespread attention, and negative sentiment could severely tarnish Activision Blizzard's reputation. Moreover, it could impact the company's image and operations in other international markets.

However, it is essential to also consider the underlying reasons behind this decision rationally. The company likely has its own business considerations and strategic plans. Although this decision has sparked controversy in the short term, it should not be hastily interpreted as abandonment of the Chinese market.

In an era characterized by diversity and openness, it is hoped that companies can better integrate into various markets globally, offering high-quality gaming experiences for players. Additionally, companies are encouraged to engage in communication and negotiation when facing challenges and difficulties, seeking mutually beneficial solutions rather than unilateral withdrawal.

In conclusion, Activision Blizzard's exit from the Chinese market has ignited widespread discussions. Regardless of whether one supports or condemns this decision, it should be approached with a composed attitude. The future expectation is that enterprises will continue to grow steadily on a global scale. Furthermore, it is hoped that companies will attach greater importance to communication with all stakeholders, in order to avoid unnecessary controversies and losses arising from singular decisions.
